content.title: Innominate (Brachiocephalic) Artery Disease
content.definition: Atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the brachiocephalic trunk (innominate artery) causing upper extremity and/or cerebrovascular symptoms. Less common than subclavian or carotid disease but carries significant stroke risk due to dual supply to right arm and right carotid.

key_concepts.description: Brachiocephalic trunk is first and largest branch of aortic arch; bifurcates into right common carotid and right subclavian arteries. Disease affects both territories
Atherosclerosis (most common); Takayasu arteritis; radiation arteritis; fibromuscular dysplasia (rare). Typically proximal stenosis at origin from aortic arch
Combined symptoms: right arm claudication/weakness; vertebrobasilar symptoms (dizziness, visual changes); right hemisphere TIA/stroke; may have both carotid and subclavian steal physiology
Diminished right arm BP and pulse; right carotid bruit; may have bruit over sternal notch; reversed right vertebral artery flow on duplex
Severe stenosis/occlusion causes reversal of flow in right common carotid (stealing from Circle of Willis to supply arm) â†’ right hemisphere ischemia during arm exercise
CTA/MRA shows innominate stenosis; duplex may show reversed right vertebral and abnormal right CCA flow; angiography for treatment planning
Primary stenting with balloon-expandable covered or bare metal stent; embolic protection challenging due to anatomy; increasing first-line option
Aorto-innominate or aorto-right carotid bypass; innominate endarterectomy (rarely done); often combined with other supra-aortic trunk procedures
Higher stroke risk than isolated subclavian disease due to right carotid territory involvement; intervention often recommended even in asymptomatic patients with severe stenosis
Often found with other atherosclerotic disease: coronary artery disease, carotid stenosis, peripheral arterial disease; screen for other territories

signs: Right arm BP lower than left

learning_objectives: Define innominate artery disease and its dual territory implications
Recognize combined arm and cerebral symptoms
clinical_pearls: Innominate disease = right arm + right carotid territory at risk
Can cause both subclavian and carotid steal
Sternal notch bruit suggests arch/innominate disease
Higher stroke risk than isolated subclavian disease
Stenting increasingly preferred over open bypass
Screen for associated CAD and PAD
common_mistakes: Treating as isolated subclavian disease (missing carotid territory risk)
Not evaluating for associated atherosclerotic disease
Ignoring asymptomatic severe stenosis (stroke risk higher than subclavian)
